details.description: If there are any errors on a marriage certificate you can correct the original registration with the register office or GRO - find out what corrections can be made, who can apply, how long it takes, what they look like
details.alternative_title: How to apply to correct a marriage certificate

parts.title: What corrections can be made
parts.body:
Corrections can only be made when the information in a marriage register is wrong (eg a mistake was made when recording a person’s occupation).

You can’t apply for a correction to show new information if circumstances change after the marriage.

You’ll need to find out if the mistake was made when entering information in the marriage register or just on the marriage certificate. To do this contact:

  • the register office where your civil marriage took place
  • the officer who was responsible for registering your religious marriage or the person who is responsible now

If the mistake is only on the marriage certificate

If the details in the register are correct, and the mistake was made when copying the details from the register onto the certificate, you can order a new copy of the certificate.

If the mistake is in the original registration

You’ll need to apply to the General Register Office (GRO) to make this correction.

The original information will always be shown in the marriage register. After the correction has been authorised, a note will be added to the margin of the register. This will explain what the correct information is and when the correction was made.

Advice

If you want further advice on applying to make a correction, contact the register office or the GRO.

parts.title: Who can apply
parts.body:
Either of the two people who married each other can apply for a correction.

If neither spouse is alive, a correction won’t be authorised.

parts.title: How to apply
parts.body:
If the mistake is in the register, you’ll need to complete an application form and send it to the General Register Office (GRO).

Download ‘Application form to correct details on a marriage registration’ (PDF, 29KB)

Any correction to a marriage entry needs to be authorised by GRO before it goes ahead at a register office or at any religious building.

Proving the record is wrong

You’ll need to provide original or certified documents to show what the correct information should have been at the time of the marriage. Send them to the register office team or to the person dealing with your correction at the religious building. They will then forward copies to GRO. This prevents your original documents from getting lost in the post.

The documents should have been valid at the time of the marriage or just before. You can’t use documents from after the date of the marriage to make a correction to a marriage entry.

Documents you can send in include a:

  • passport
  • photocard driving licence
  • bank, building society or credit card statement dated within 3 months before the marriage
  • letter from a hospital or doctor
  • letter from a government department

If you can’t send in proof, corrections can’t usually be made.

Witnessing the correction

There must always be 2 witnesses to a correction to a marriage record - they can be either:

  • the people who got married
  • nominated by the people who got married

Witnesses don’t have to have been at the original marriage. However, they do need to know about the information that’s going to be corrected.

How much it costs

It’s free to make a correction to the register.

It costs £9.25 to get a new certificate that shows the correction note.

parts.title: How long applications take
parts.body:
If you’re making an application to the General Register Office (GRO) and there are no problems with your application, you should receive a reply within 5 working days.

If the GRO asks you for more information, each further reply from them may take up to 20 working days.

Applications may take longer to process in exceptional circumstances.

parts.title: When the correction has been approved
parts.body:
When the General Register Office (GRO) has approved the correction, it will send authorisation and details of the correction to the register office or religious building. You’ll then need to arrange for whoever is going to witness the correction to attend the register office or religious building to witness the correction being carried out.

After the correction has been carried out you can buy a new marriage certificate that shows the original information along with a note of the corrected details.
